awd_titl_txt: Together for the Planet 2.0: Community Environmental Scholars Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Community Environmental Scholars Program (CESP) will provide scholarships and cohort-based training and support for at least 36 low-income junior and senior students who are STEM majors and also enrolled in an Environmental Studies major or certificate. Via a weekly seminar taught by STEM faculty members, CESP connects students with their peers, links them to a network of CESP graduates, and provides avenues in the community for them to connect their passion for the environment with a commitment to service. To identify potential applicants, we work with our Office of Student Financial Aid, current CESP students, and the wider campus community. Via a campus scholarship portal, we receive applications fall and spring.  Those accepted form a team (cohort) in the weekly seminar that takes on increasingly complex leadership roles over time. Ultimately, our goal is to improve the retention of our students in their STEM disciplines by offering relevant scientific content, opportunities to build confidence, and enhanced career skills that will allow them to work in diverse teams to address the real-world challenges faced the communities in which they live.

While existing research already suggests that cohort-based programs improve student retention within STEM disciplines, there is little or no research that evaluates whether interdisciplinary STEM cohorts (such as those in CESP) can improve student performance, retention, and graduation rates. We will use statistical comparisons to investigate our diverse cohort design and determine if these important educational outcomes differ between our CESP students and a comparison group of STEM students who also enrolled in Environmental Studies but who did not participate in CESP. The results of our analysis will be shared with institutional peers at conferences and with the broader community through journal articles and public outreach.

por.por_cntn:
Our project, Together for the Planet 2.0: Community Environmental Scholars Program, launched in 2016 and ran for five years plus an additional one-year extension.

Oue primary goal was to assist 36 junior and senior STEM majors with financial need to successfully complete their degrees at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.  At the end of our grant, we exceeded this goal, supporting 50 students who simultaneously were pursuing a major or certificate in environmental studies.  As of September 2022, 46 of these students remained in our program and in their STEM major, a retention rate of over 90%.

Our secondary goal was to contribute knowledge about what our STEM students need and how well they learn. We accomplished this goal, in spite of having to switch our research team in the fourth year of the award. Our new team collected new data sets, working to better understand the student experience by conducting interviews with current and past students, observing classroom interactions, and analyzing student assignments.

Through our investigations we gained insights into the challenges that students face, including feelings of isolation from their peers in their STEM degrees. Our program helped address these challenges by providing monetary, interpersonal, and peer support. We also provided instructors who were mentors and facilitators, rather than simply content instructors. Student friendships lasted across multiple semesters. Students reported that the teamwork was more beneficial than the group homework in their majors and came to ground their science learning in a community context.

Background

The Nelson Institute for Environmental Studies offers a unique home for STEM students because all environmental studies majors must have a second major. Currently, over 1/3 of our environmental studies majors have STEM disciplines as their primary major; for those with environmental studies certificates, 2/3 have STEM majors. Thus, we have a pool of STEM students that guarantees both a diverse set of STEM majors and a common interest in the environment.

Over 33,000 undergraduates attend UW-Madison each year. While mentoring programs exist for freshmen, fewer opportunities exist for juniors and seniors. Our S-STEM project aimed to build that community, particularly for students with financial need

Research on student outcomes shows that learning science in the context of real-world issues, such as those in environmental studies/science courses, is effective for all students but especially so for women and those from minority groups. We also knew that community service could serve as a contextual scaffold for learning in the sciences. We built our Community Environmental Scholars Program around a 1-credit weekly seminar that utilized best practices in community service learning, provided students with professional development opportunities, and gave a cohort-based learning experience.

Merit

Our S-STEM project, the Community Environmental Scholars Program (CESP), models a real-world setting in which people from STEM fields work with those in other disciplines to accomplish common goals. Our theme of environmental concern linked to community service allows us to attract students from a diverse group of majors: environmental science, chemical engineering, biochemistry, wildlife ecology, geoscience, and horticulture (to name but a few). Our students work in cohorts that meet for three or four semesters. With their cohort, students volunteer for community organizations, non-profits, and governmental agencies around the city. By linking service, professional development, and a strong cohort experience, we build the relationships with students that are a prerequisite for effective advising and mentoring. Our approach has proven successful over a span of the five-year grant. On average, our S-STEM students graduated in 4 years with a GPA of 3.4.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our program stem from the long-term successes of our students: they will make significant contributions in their professional and personal lives.

Of the 46 scholarship recipients who remained in the program, 41 had graduated from UW-Madison by Fall 2022 and the remaining 5 were on track to graduate. We received post-graduation information from 36 of our 41 graduates.  Of these, 18 are enrolled in or have completed graduate programs in STEM disciplines or in STEM-related fields such as public health, science education, or environmental management.  An additional 19 self-report that they held a STEM-related job, some while simultaneously pursuing a graduate degree. The remaining students are pursuing graduate work and/or employment in non-STEM fields.

In CESP, students were challenged to apply community-building skills in their personal and professional development. The classroom environment reinforced best practices in community engagement: reciprocal relationships, power sharing, leveraging strengths and assets to address needs and challenges, and recognizing that all people have valuable knowledge and expertise through a variety of ways of knowing. Over 25 outside organizations partnered with our students.

Our students see themselves as part of a network of professionals dedicated to both environmental knowledge and community service. This community of scholars is a lasting legacy of the support we have received from the NSF.
